1.text: And Job addeth to lift up his simile, and saith:—

2.text: Who doth make me as in months past, As in the days of God’s preserving me?

3.text: In His causing His lamp to shine on my head, By His light I walk through darkness.

4.text: As I have been in days of my maturity, And the counsel of God upon my tent.

5.text: When yet the Mighty One is with me. Round about me—my young ones,

6.text: When washing my goings with butter, And the firm rock is with me rivulets of oil.

7.text: When I go out to the gate by the city, In a broad place I prepare my seat.

8.text: Seen me have youths, and they, been hidden, And the aged have risen—they stood up.

9.text: Princes have kept in words, And a hand they place on their mouth.

10.text: The voice of leaders hath been hidden, And their tongue to the palate hath cleaved.

11.text: For the ear heard, and declareth me happy, And the eye hath seen, and testifieth to me.

12.text: For I deliver the afflicted who is crying, And the fatherless who hath no helper.

13.text: The blessing of the perishing cometh on me, And the heart of the widow I cause to sing.

14.text: Righteousness I have put on, and it clotheth me, As a robe and a diadem my justice.

15.text: Eyes I have been to the blind, And feet to the lame am I.

16.text: A father I am to the needy, And the cause I have not known I search out.

17.text: And I break the jaw-teeth of the perverse, And from his teeth I cast away prey.

18.text: And I say, ‘With my nest I expire, And as the sand I multiply days.’

19.text: My root is open unto the waters, And dew doth lodge on my branch.

20.text: My honour is fresh with me, And my bow in my hand is renewed.

21.text: To me they have hearkened, Yea, they wait, and are silent for my counsel.

22.text: After my word they change not, And on them doth my speech drop,

23.text: And they wait as for rain for me, And their mouth they have opened wide As for the latter rain.

24.text: I laugh unto them—they give no credence, And the light of my face cause not to fall.

25.text: I choose their way, and sit head, And I dwell as a king in a troop, When mourners he doth comfort.
